Award.AwardTitle: LTREB: Population and community ecology of desert winter annuals
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will record the population and community dynamics of desert winter annual plants on permanent plots first monitored 26 years ago at the Desert Laboratory near Tucson, AZ, USA. It will provide understanding of demographic variation and its role in population and community ecology. Soil seed reserves will be monitored to determine the fraction of seeds that germinate and the fraction that persist in dormancy. Experiments will determine the role of granivores in lowering the populations of desert annuals and determine when seeds die during the year. Models will be constructed to determine the role of soil seed banks in buffering populations and how species differences promote coexistence and species diversity. Calibrating the 25 year data set with weather data will permit the prediction of biotic response to climate change.

Desert annual plants have played an important role as model organisms in the development of understanding of how organisms adapt to variable and unpredictable environments. They have also been used to exemplify ideas about non-equilibrium community dynamics. This project will provide the best available long-term data to test these ideas. This research will combine research and education by involving students in mentoring and research, emphasizing underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this grant was to determine how plants adapt to and coexist in variable and unpredictable environments, using Sonoran Desert annuals as a model system.

Goals and outcomes:

1) To collect data on the population dynamics of winter annuals. We aimed to understand the mechanisms underlying observed population dynamics. This is critical for evaluating and developing theories about species coexistence and life history adaptations, especially in the context of variable environments. Pursuant to this goal we have collected five years of long-term data in this now 30 year continuous data set. The results demonstrate the highly variable dynamics of desert annuals and document long-term trends attributable to warming and drying. The variability of weather during these 5 years is beyond the envelope we found in the 20st century. There is speculation that this is “the new normal”. This new hydroclimatology will affect the long-term trajectory of this community and influence the ecological and evolutionary processes we have been documenting.  We found that, in any given year, species with high water use efficiency germinated and reproduced earlier in the season than species with low WUE, whereas low-WUE species had shorter reproductive phases. This helps clarify the mechanism by which functional trait values determine species' dynamics.

2) To develop an improved empirical insight into the timing and magnitude of seed mortality. A better understanding of seed mortality strengthens our ability to answer our other research questions. We collected seed bank samples in early May (after reproduction) to complement our February samples (after germination; before reproduction) to help us better parse the timing and magnitude of seed mortality. We are able to separate the May seeds into fresh (produced during the current spring) and old (carryover from at least the previous year).

3) To explore the role of seed predation in species coexistence. Frequency-dependent seed predation is an understudied potential species coexistence mechanism that is likely to influence the ecological and evolutionary dynamics of desert annuals. We have conducted experiments on frequency-dependent predation by desert rodents. Granivory is known to be important in desert ecosystems (Brown et al. 1979). Also, species vary greatly in seed abundance over time. If granivores switch seed preferences to species at high density they would have a strong diversity promoting effect (Hulme 1996, Chesson and Kuang 2008). We varied the frequency of seeds of three common species of desert annuals presented in sand trays to nocturnal rodents. The results demonstrated a clear pattern of frequency-dependent seed removal: each species was preferred when it was at high frequency (Fig. 1). This is the first clear demonstration of this potentially important coexistence mechanism for desert annuals. 

4) To model bet hedging, species coexistence and multidecadal response to climate change. The Sonoran Desert annual model system, with its well-understood population dynamics and species’ functional biology, is becoming a powerful tool to apply to the grand challenges in ecology, which include predicting the behavior of communities and the scaling of individual function to understand  ecological and environmental processes. As proposed, we quantified the magnitude of storage effect species coexistence using the long-term data together with a community dynamics model. We measured the low-density growth rate advantage to be about 10%.
